Award.AwardTitle: Fractional Partial Differential Equations and Related Nonlocal Models: Fast Numerical Methods, Analysis, and Application
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project proposes to develop a novel mathematical modeling of micro- and nano-fluidics, which intersects engineering, biochemistry, nanotechnology, and biotechnology. The study of micro-and nano-fluidics has great potential to revolutionize the methods in biological and chemical applications, which has wide applications to the design of systems in which low volumes of fluids are processed to achieve multiplexing, automation, and high-throughput screening. Micro- and nano-fluidics is used widely in the development of inkjet printheads, DNA chips, lab-on-a-chip technology, micro-propulsion, and micro-thermal technologies. The project will also provide advanced interdisciplinary training to graduate and undergraduate students. All of these activities will have broad and long-lasting impacts and contribute directly to the intellectual infrastructure of the nation.

Nonlocal models such as fractional partial differential equations (FPDEs), fractional Laplacian, and peridynamics are emerging as powerful tools for modeling challenging phenomena including anomalous transport and long-range time memory or spatial interactions in a wide range of fields such as biology, physics, chemistry, finance, engineering, and solute transport in groundwater. These models provide more appropriate description of many important problems in applications than integer-order PDE models do. Two of the main reasons that nonlocal models have not been used extensively so far are as follows: (1) They generate numerical schemes with dense matrices and solutions with strongly local behavior, which are significantly more expensive to solve numerically than traditional integer-order PDE models. A naive simulation of a three-dimensional linear problem with a moderate number of grid points may take state of the art supercomputers hundreds of years to finish and so deemed unrealistic. (2) Nonlocal models introduce mathematical difficulties, which were not encountered in the context of integer-order PDEs. It is proposed to effectively address both points at this juncture. The fast numerical methods proposed herein will provide significant computational benefits for nonlocal models, and will facilitate their applications. Preliminary numerical experiments of a simple three-dimensional fractional PDE showed that the proposed method reduced the CPU time from 2 months and 25 days by a traditional method to 5.74 seconds and reduced storage significantly. The proposed mathematical and numerical analysis will provide a solid theoretical foundation for nonlocal models and related numerical approximations. The fast and accurate numerical methods and rigorous mathematical analysis results will be applied in the development of a novel mathematical modeling of micro- and nano-fluidics. The resulting mathematical model will be utilized in the study of micro- and nano-fluidics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The classical diffusion equation was set up by Fick and was studied independently by Einstein from first principles and by Pearson via random walk, under the assumptions that the underlying particle jumps have (i) a mean free path and (ii) a mean waiting time. Its solutions are characterized by exponentially decaying tails. However, assumptions (i) and (ii) hold only for the diffusive transport in homogeneous media when field test showed that the solute plumes decay exponentially.                                               

Field test also showed that diffusive transport in heterogeneous media exhibits power-law decaying tails, to which Fickian diffusion equations often fail to provide satisfactory descriptions. Fractional diffusion equations were derived assuming that their solutions exhibit power-law decaying tails, which explains why they can accurately model the long-term behavior of anomalously diffusive transport. However, fractional diffusion equations present new difficulties that are not common in the context of integer-order diffusion equations.

The project outcomes can be summarized as follows: (i) An improved, physically relevant fractional diffusion model was studied, which eliminates the nonphysical behavior of conventional fractional diffusion model, e.g., near the initial time and the boundary of the physical domain and provides a better description of anomalously diffusive transport. (ii) Because of their nonlocal feature, fractional diffusion equations and related nonlocal models are computationally significantly more expensive than integer-order analogues. Fast numerical methods were developed for fractional diffusion models and nonlocal models, by exploring the mathematical structures of their numerical discretization such as translation invariance and rank deficiency that are inherent in the models and their numerical discretization. (iii) Supporting mathematical and numerical analysis was carried out rigorously to solidify the numerical approximations to fractional diffusion models.

Intellectual Merits: The new mathematical, numerical, computational issues that are present in fractional diffusion equations are some of the main reasons why these nonlocal models have not been used extensively so far. The research findings in this project address several of these issues, which helps promoting the research advances in the area of fractional diffusion equations and their applications.  

Broad Impacts: The research activities in the project provided interdisciplinary training to students, via the students’ participation of the project and the incorporation of the results from the research outcomes of the project into classroom teaching. All of these activities will have broad and long-lasting impacts and contribute directly to the intellectual infrastructure of the nation.
